title: Psalms Chapter 40 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 40 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 40 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 40.

questions.question: According to Psalms 40:1, what did the LORD do when the Psalmist waited patiently?
options: He inclined unto me and heard my cry
He sent a prophet to me
questions.correctAnswer: He inclined unto me and heard my cry
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:1 states that the LORD inclined unto the Psalmist and heard his cry when he waited patiently.

questions.question: What did God do for the Psalmist out of the horrible pit according to Psalms 40:2?
options: Set my feet upon a rock
questions.correctAnswer: Set my feet upon a rock
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:2 says God brought the Psalmist out of a horrible pit and set his feet upon a rock.

questions.question: What did God put in the Psalmist's mouth as mentioned in Psalms 40:3?
questions.correctAnswer: A new song
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:3 explains that God put a new song in the Psalmist's mouth, even praise unto God.

questions.question: Who is blessed according to Psalms 40:4?
options: He that maketh the LORD his trust
questions.correctAnswer: He that maketh the LORD his trust
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:4 states that blessed is the man who makes the LORD his trust.

questions.question: According to Psalms 40:5, how are God's wonderful works described?
questions.correctAnswer: More than can be numbered
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:5 says God's wonderful works are so many they cannot be numbered.

questions.question: What did God not desire according to Psalms 40:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrifice and offering
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:6 states that God did not desire sacrifice and offering.

questions.question: In Psalms 40:7, what is written in the volume of the book?
options: Fear not, for I am with you
questions.correctAnswer: Lo, I come
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:7 says the Psalmist said, 'Lo, I come: in the volume of the book it is written of me.'

questions.question: What does the Psalmist delight to do according to Psalms 40:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Do God's will
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:8 states the Psalmist delights to do God's will.

questions.question: What has the Psalmist not refrained from doing in the great congregation according to Psalms 40:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Preached righteousness
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:9 says the Psalmist has preached righteousness in the great congregation without refraining his lips.

questions.question: What does the Psalmist ask God not to withhold from him in Psalms 40:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Tender mercies
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:11 requests God not to withhold tender mercies from the Psalmist.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 40:12 says the Psalmist has few troubles around him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:12 states the Psalmist is surrounded by innumerable evils, so this statement is false.

questions.question: True or False: The Psalmist asks God to make haste to help him in Psalms 40:13.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:13 clearly asks God to make haste to help the Psalmist.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 40:16 encourages those who seek God to rejoice and be glad in Him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:16 says those who seek God should rejoice and be glad in Him.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 40:17: 'But I am poor and needy; yet the Lord thinketh _____ me.'
questions.correctAnswer: upon
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:17 says, 'yet the Lord thinketh upon me.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 40:10, what has the Psalmist not concealed from the great congregation?
questions.correctAnswer: Lovingkindness and truth
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:10 states the Psalmist has not concealed God's lovingkindness and truth from the great congregation.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 40 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 40 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 40, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in difficult times?
options: Trusting God brings stability and sets our feet on a solid foundation
God expects us to face trials alone without asking for help
Trials are a sign that God has abandoned us
We should rely only on our own strength during hardships
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God brings stability and sets our feet on a solid foundation
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:1-2 teaches that waiting patiently for the LORD results in Him inclining to us and delivering us from difficult situations, setting our feet upon a rock and establishing our goings. Trust in God brings stability through trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 40 teach about the importance of sharing God’s faithfulness with others?
options: We should declare God’s faithfulness openly to encourage others
Faithfulness is a private matter and should not be shared publicly
Only pastors should preach about God's righteousness
Sharing faithfulness is optional and not important
questions.correctAnswer: We should declare God’s faithfulness openly to encourage others
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 emphasize preaching righteousness and declaring God's faithfulness and lovingkindness openly before the great congregation, encouraging believers to share their testimony.

questions.question: Which attitude toward God’s law does Psalms 40 encourage for practical Christian living?
options: Delighting in God’s will and having His law within our hearts
Only obeying God's law when convenient
Focusing on human traditions rather than God's law
questions.correctAnswer: Delighting in God’s will and having His law within our hearts
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:8 states that the psalmist delights to do God's will and that His law is within his heart, highlighting joyful obedience as essential for daily living.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to rely on sacrifices and offerings instead of obedience. What insight does Psalms 40 provide?
options: God desires obedience and opened ears rather than sacrifices
Burnt offerings are the most important part of worship
Sin offerings alone can make us right with God
Sacrifices are the only way to earn God’s favor
questions.correctAnswer: God desires obedience and opened ears rather than sacrifices
questions.explanation: Verse 6 emphasizes that God did not desire sacrifices or burnt offerings but opened ears, implying obedience and willingness to listen are more valuable than ritual offerings.

questions.question: How does Psalms 40 teach about perseverance through trials and prayer?
options: We should earnestly pray for deliverance and trust God’s timing
Prayer is unnecessary since trials are deserved
Giving up during trials is acceptable
We must handle trials without asking for God’s help
questions.correctAnswer: We should earnestly pray for deliverance and trust God’s timing
questions.explanation: Verses 13 and 17 show the psalmist pleading for God to deliver him and make no delay, demonstrating persistent prayer and trust in God’s help during difficult times.

questions.question: What does Psalms 40:4 teach us about humility and choosing whom to trust?
options: Blessed is the one who trusts the LORD and does not respect the proud or liars
Trusting proud people leads to blessings
We should respect those who turn aside to lies
Humility is not related to whom we trust
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed is the one who trusts the LORD and does not respect the proud or liars
questions.explanation: Verse 4 highlights the blessing on those who place their trust in the LORD and avoid prideful and deceitful people, encouraging humility and discernment in relationships.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 40 emphasizes that God’s works and thoughts toward us are too many to count.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 5 declares that God's wonderful works and thoughts toward us cannot be reckoned or numbered, expressing God's abundant mercy and care.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the psalmist’s attitude toward proclaiming God's truth in a congregation as seen in Psalms 40?
options: He openly preached righteousness without restraint
He avoided sharing God’s truths in public
He only whispered God's word privately
He shared God's truth only when asked
questions.correctAnswer: He openly preached righteousness without restraint
questions.explanation: Verse 9 shows the psalmist preaching righteousness in the great congregation without refraining his lips, demonstrating boldness and commitment to public witness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 40 encourage us to respond to enemies or those who wish us harm?
options: Pray that they be ashamed and put to shame
questions.correctAnswer: Pray that they be ashamed and put to shame
questions.explanation: Verses 14-15 instruct the psalmist to ask God to make those who seek to destroy him ashamed and confounded, showing reliance on God’s justice rather than personal revenge.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 40 teaches that God thinks upon the poor and needy and is our help and deliverer.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 17 clearly states the psalmist’s condition of being poor and needy and affirms that the LORD thinks upon him as his help and deliverer.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "He hath put a new ______ in my mouth, even praise unto our God."
questions.correctAnswer: song
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states that God has put a new song in the psalmist’s mouth, symbolizing renewed joy and praise toward God.

questions.question: What does Psalms 40 teach about the role of obedience compared to ritual sacrifices?
options: Obedience is more important than sacrifices
Sacrifices are the only way to please God
Obedience and sacrifices are equally irrelevant
Sacrifices replace the need for obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience is more important than sacrifices
questions.explanation: Verse 6 emphasizes that God did not desire sacrifices and offerings but rather obedience and listening, indicating the primacy of obedience over ritual.

questions.question: How does Psalms 40 guide us in maintaining integrity in daily life and work?
options: By openly declaring righteousness and faithfulness
By hiding our beliefs from others
By focusing only on personal gain
questions.correctAnswer: By openly declaring righteousness and faithfulness
questions.explanation: Verses 9-10 show the psalmist openly preaching righteousness and declaring God's faithfulness, encouraging transparency and integrity as a witness in all areas of life.

questions.question: According to Psalms 40, what should those who love God’s salvation do continually?
questions.correctAnswer: Say continually, 'The LORD be magnified'
questions.explanation: Verse 16 encourages those who love God’s salvation to rejoice and say continually, 'The LORD be magnified,' highlighting continual praise and gratitude.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by sins and troubles. Based on Psalms 40, what biblical truth could encourage them?
options: God’s tender mercies and lovingkindness continually preserve us
Our sins are too many for God to forgive
We must hide our troubles from others
God does not notice our sufferings
questions.correctAnswer: God’s tender mercies and lovingkindness continually preserve us
questions.explanation: Verse 11 asks God not to withhold tender mercies and lovingkindness, assuring believers that God’s mercy preserves us even when overwhelmed by sin and trouble (verses 11-12).

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 40 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 40.

questions.question: In Psalms 40:2, what metaphor does David use to describe his deliverance by God?
options: He brought me up out of an horrible pit
He parted the Red Sea for me
He built me a house of cedar
questions.correctAnswer: He brought me up out of an horrible pit
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:2 uses the metaphor of being brought up out of an horrible pit and miry clay to illustrate God's deliverance and establishment of the psalmist's steps.

questions.question: Which phrase from Psalms 40:3 indicates a theme of new praise given to God?
options: He hath put a new song in my mouth
He maketh the LORD his trust
Many, O LORD my God, are thy wonderful works
Sacrifice and offering thou didst not desire
questions.correctAnswer: He hath put a new song in my mouth
questions.explanation: Verse 3 explicitly states that God has put a new song in the psalmist's mouth, symbolizing renewed joy and praise.

questions.question: According to Psalms 40:6, what does God not desire from the psalmist?
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrifice and offering
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:6 says 'Sacrifice and offering thou didst not desire', highlighting a shift from ritual sacrifices to obedience and hearing God's will.

questions.question: In Psalms 40:7, what does the psalmist say is written about him in the 'volume of the book'?
options: The stone rejected by the builders
questions.correctAnswer: Lo, I come
questions.explanation: Verse 7 quotes the psalmist saying, 'Lo, I come: in the volume of the book it is written of me', indicating a prophetic or covenantal fulfillment.

questions.question: What is the significance of 'mine ears hast thou opened' in Psalms 40:6 within the ancient Near Eastern covenant context?
options: It symbolizes obedient submission to God's law
It refers to the physical healing of deafness
It means the psalmist can hear angelic voices
It signifies the start of temple worship
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes obedient submission to God's law
questions.explanation: In ancient covenant contexts, 'opening the ears' metaphorically represents willingness to listen and obey God's commands, as seen in Psalms 40:6.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Psalms 40:12 where David describes his iniquities as 'more than the hairs of mine head'?
questions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole
questions.explanation: The description of sins being 'more than the hairs of mine head' is an example of hyperbole, emphasizing the psalmist’s overwhelming burden as in Psalms 40:12.

questions.question: How does the theme of trust in the LORD in Psalms 40:4 develop throughout the chapter?
options: It progresses from patient waiting to confident deliverance
It shifts from doubt to despair
It focuses solely on rituals and sacrifices
It emphasizes human wisdom over divine help
questions.correctAnswer: It progresses from patient waiting to confident deliverance
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:4 blesses those who trust in the LORD, and the chapter moves from patient waiting (verse 1) to confident pleas for deliverance (verses 13-17).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 40 emphasizes that burnt offerings and sin offerings are required for God's acceptance.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:6 clearly states that burnt offerings and sin offerings were not required, emphasizing obedience over ritual sacrifice.

questions.question: In Psalms 40:9 and 40:10, what public action does David highlight regarding God's righteousness and salvation?
options: He declares and preaches them openly
He keeps them secret to avoid persecution
He writes them only in private journals
He teaches them exclusively to priests
questions.correctAnswer: He declares and preaches them openly
questions.explanation: Verses 9 and 10 state that David has not refrained or concealed preaching God's righteousness, faithfulness, and salvation to the great congregation.

questions.question: Which New Testament figure is seen as fulfilling the prophetic foreshadowing in Psalms 40:7-8 about doing God's will?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: The New Testament references Psalms 40:7-8 (Hebrews 10:5-7) as prophecy fulfilled by Jesus Christ in his obedience to God's will.

questions.question: What does David request in Psalms 40:13, reflecting an urgent need?
options: O LORD, make haste to help me
Build a house for the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: O LORD, make haste to help me
questions.explanation: Verse 13 expresses a plea for swift deliverance, indicating David’s urgent dependence on God’s intervention.

questions.question: Which phrase in Psalms 40:16 reflects a communal rejoicing in God's salvation?
options: Let all those that seek thee rejoice and be glad in thee
Blessed is that man that maketh the LORD his trust
Many shall see it, and fear
Thou art my help and my deliverer
questions.correctAnswer: Let all those that seek thee rejoice and be glad in thee
questions.explanation: Verse 16 calls for collective joy and gladness towards God among all who seek Him, highlighting communal worship.

questions.question: In Psalms 40:17, how does David describe his condition, and how does God respond?
options: Poor and needy; the Lord thinks upon me
Rich and powerful; the Lord honors me
Blind and mute; the Lord heals me
Lost and wandering; the Lord guides me
questions.correctAnswer: Poor and needy; the Lord thinks upon me
questions.explanation: David admits his poverty and neediness but trusts that the Lord remembers and helps him, as stated in verse 17.

questions.question: Which cultural practice is indirectly critiqued in Psalms 40:6 by de-emphasizing sacrifices?
questions.correctAnswer: Temple animal sacrifices
questions.explanation: By stating that God did not desire sacrifice and offering, Psalms 40:6 critiques the overreliance on temple animal sacrifices prevalent in ancient Israelite worship.

questions.question: What does Psalms 40:14-15 ask to happen to those who seek to destroy the psalmist's soul?
options: Let them be ashamed and confounded
Let them be honored and praised
Let them be healed and restored
Let them be silent and blessed
questions.correctAnswer: Let them be ashamed and confounded
questions.explanation: Verses 14 and 15 petition God to shame and confound the enemies of the psalmist, reflecting a common ancient Near Eastern plea for justice.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 40 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 40 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 40, what is the foundational attitude that precedes God's intervention in the psalmist's life?
questions.correctAnswer: Faithful waiting and patient trust
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:1 emphasizes the psalmist's patient waiting for the LORD, which precedes God's inclination and hearing of his cry. This is consistent with scriptures like Lamentations 3:25 and Isaiah 40:31 where waiting on God is affirmed as foundational.

questions.question: In Psalms 40, what metaphor does the psalmist use to describe his deliverance by God?
options: God lifted him from the miry clay and set his feet upon a rock
God parted the Red Sea for him
God gave him wings like an eagle
God built a tower of refuge
questions.correctAnswer: God lifted him from the miry clay and set his feet upon a rock
questions.explanation: Psalm 40:2 uses the imagery of God bringing the psalmist out of a horrible pit and miry clay and establishing his feet upon a rock, symbolizing salvation, stability, and a firm foundation. This is echoed in 1 Samuel 2:8 and Isaiah 51:1-2 as a symbol of God's saving act.

questions.question: What does the 'new song' in Psalms 40 symbolize in biblical theology?
options: A new musical composition unrelated to God
Praise for God's salvation and a testimony to others
A call for war against enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Praise for God's salvation and a testimony to others
questions.explanation: Psalm 40:3 speaks of God putting a new song in the psalmist's mouth, which is praise unto God. This new song often symbolizes new acts of salvation and joyful testimony (see Isaiah 42:10, Revelation 5:9, Exodus 15:1).

questions.question: Who is described as blessed in Psalms 40:4?
options: One who makes the LORD their trust and does not respect the proud or liars
One who gains wealth and power
One who remains silent in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: One who makes the LORD their trust and does not respect the proud or liars
questions.explanation: Psalm 40:4 blesses the man who trusts in the LORD and rejects pride and falsehood, highlighting the biblical theme of humility and faith (cf. Proverbs 3:5-6, Jeremiah 17:7, James 4:6).

questions.question: How does Psalms 40 describe God's works and thoughts towards His people?
options: They are few and easily counted
They are wonderful and too numerous to be reckoned
questions.correctAnswer: They are wonderful and too numerous to be reckoned
questions.explanation: Psalm 40:5 describes God's works and thoughts toward His people as numerous and wonderful beyond number, reflecting the infinite wisdom and lovingkindness of God (see Psalm 103:17-18, Isaiah 55:8-9, Romans 11:33).

questions.question: According to Psalms 40, what does God not desire as a means of approach?
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrifice and burnt offerings
questions.explanation: Psalm 40:6 states that God did not desire sacrifice and burnt offerings but rather obedience, reflecting the prophetic emphasis seen in Hosea 6:6 and Isaiah 1:11-17 that God values a heart aligned with His will over ritual sacrifices.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'mine ears hast thou opened' in Psalms 40:6 signify in a Christological and theological context?
options: Spiritual obedience and submission to God's will
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual obedience and submission to God's will
questions.explanation: The phrase 'mine ears hast thou opened' (Psalm 40:6) symbolizes the willingness to obey God's will rather than merely perform sacrifices. This echoes Isaiah 50:4-5 where the Servant listens obediently to God, a messianic prophecy fulfilled in Christ (Hebrews 10:5-7).

questions.question: In Psalms 40, how does the psalmist express his attitude towards God's law?
options: He finds it burdensome and restrictive
He delights to do God's will and has the law within his heart
He ignores it in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: He delights to do God's will and has the law within his heart
questions.explanation: Psalm 40:8 reveals the psalmist's delight in doing God's will and having His law written in his heart, a theme echoed in Jeremiah 31:33 and fulfilled in the New Covenant promises (Hebrews 10:16).

questions.question: What is the psalmist's declared public ministry in Psalms 40?
options: He preached righteousness in the great congregation without restraint
He remained silent out of fear
He performed miracles to gain followers
questions.correctAnswer: He preached righteousness in the great congregation without restraint
questions.explanation: Psalm 40:9-10 indicates the psalmist boldly proclaimed God's righteousness, faithfulness, salvation, lovingkindness, and truth openly. This reflects the prophetic and apostolic call to fearless proclamation (Acts 4:20, 2 Timothy 4:2).

questions.question: What plea does the psalmist make regarding God's mercy in Psalms 40?
options: That God withhold mercy until he is perfect
That God continually preserve him with lovingkindness and truth
That God punish him for his sins
questions.correctAnswer: That God continually preserve him with lovingkindness and truth
questions.explanation: Psalm 40:11 is a plea for God not to withhold tender mercies but to continually preserve the psalmist by lovingkindness and truth, emphasizing God's covenant faithfulness (Lamentations 3:22-23, Exodus 34:6-7).

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe his condition in Psalms 40:12?
options: Surrounded by innumerable evils and overwhelmed by iniquities
questions.correctAnswer: Surrounded by innumerable evils and overwhelmed by iniquities
questions.explanation: Psalm 40:12 portrays the psalmist as encircled by evils and overwhelmed by his sins, causing his heart to fail, which reflects the universal human condition apart from divine grace (Psalm 38:4, Romans 3:23).

questions.question: What urgent request does the psalmist make to God in Psalms 40:13?
options: That God hasten to deliver and help him
That God allow him to suffer more
questions.correctAnswer: That God hasten to deliver and help him
questions.explanation: Psalms 40:13 is a cry for immediate deliverance and help, illustrating the psalmist's dependence on God's timely intervention, consistent with biblical prayers for swift salvation (Psalm 70:1, Isaiah 33:2).

questions.question: What is the psalmist's attitude towards those who seek to destroy him in Psalms 40:14-15?
options: He prays that they be ashamed and desolate
He seeks to reconcile with them
questions.correctAnswer: He prays that they be ashamed and desolate
questions.explanation: In Psalms 40:14-15, the psalmist asks God to bring shame and desolation upon his enemies, reflecting the biblical justice motif where God vindicates the righteous (Psalm 35:4-6, Romans 12:19).

questions.question: Who are called to rejoice and be glad in Psalms 40:16?
options: Those who seek the LORD and love His salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Those who seek the LORD and love His salvation
questions.explanation: Psalm 40:16 calls all who seek God and love His salvation to rejoice and magnify the LORD, aligning with the universal call to worship and praise in scriptures like Psalm 105:3 and Philippians 4:4.

questions.question: How does the psalmist describe himself in relation to God in Psalms 40:17?
options: As poor and needy, yet remembered and helped by God
questions.correctAnswer: As poor and needy, yet remembered and helped by God
questions.explanation: Psalm 40:17 confesses poverty and neediness but affirms that the LORD thinks upon him and is his help and deliverer, highlighting the biblical theme of divine mercy toward the humble (Psalm 34:6, Matthew 5:3).
